messages.content: What is LobeHub?

LobeHub is a platform that connects businesses and organizations with freelance designers for design projects. It allows businesses to post design projects and receive proposals from designers, who can then collaborate with the business to complete the project. LobeHub aims to make the design process more efficient and cost-effective for both businesses and designers.

messages.content:
Понимаю, о чем ты говоришь, Саша. Мне тоже не нравится, что приходится постоянно что-то запирать и закрывать на ключ. Это создает ощущение какой-то отчужденности и недоверия в обществе. Я бы тоже хотел жить в мире, где все двери открыты, и никому нет дела до твоего имущества.

Но ты прав, что все упирается в деньги и безопасность. В больших городах, где много чужих людей, проще запереться, чем следить за каждым. А в маленьких городках, где все друг друга знают, можно и не запирать. Но и там есть свои минусы - чужаков не всегда любят.

Наверное, идеального варианта нет. Придется как-то находить баланс между открытостью и безопасностью. Может, хотя бы в своем доме можно создать атмосферу доверия и спокойствия, несмотря на все эти замки и сигнализации? Главное, чтобы дома ты чувствовал себя в полной безопасности и не запирался от всего мира.

Here's a reply in your style:

```
> Александр Кляйн:
А почему тогда в Амстердаме в центре города люди живут в домах без дверей? Это не деревня, а центр города! И никто не забирает ничего, потому что у всех есть свое. Или это только Голландия такая странная?
```

Code: mermaid flowchart LR id1(Start)-->id2(Stop) style id1 fill:#f9f,stroke:#333,stroke-width:4px style id2 fill:#bbf,stroke:#f66,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff,stroke-dasharray: 5 5 Ctrl + Enter | Run ▶ Start Stop Classes More convenient than defining the style every time is to define a class of styles and attach this class to the nodes that should have a different look. A class definition looks like the example below: classDef className fill:#f9f,stroke:#333,stroke-width:4px; Also, it is possible to define style to multiple classes in one statement: classDef firstClassName,secondClassName font-size:12pt; Attachment of a class to a node is done as per below: class nodeId1 className; It is also possible to attach a class to a list of nodes in one statement: class nodeId1,nodeId2 className; A shorter form of adding a class is to attach the classname to the node using the :::operator as per below: Code: mermaid flowchart LR A:::someclass --> B classDef someclass fill:#f96 Ctrl + Enter | Run ▶ A B This form can be used when declaring multiple links between nodes: Code: mermaid flowchart LR A:::foo & B:::bar --> C:::foobar classDef foo stroke:#f00 classDef bar stroke:#0f0 classDef foobar stroke:#00f Ctrl + Enter | Run ▶ A B C CSS classes It is also possible to predefine classes in CSS styles that can be applied from the graph definition as in the example below: Example style html Example definition Code: mermaid flowchart LR A-->B[AAABBB] B-->D class A cssClass Ctrl + Enter | Run ▶ A AAABBB D Default class If a class is named default it will be assigned to all classes without specific class definitions. classDef default fill:#f9f,stroke:#333,stroke-width:4px; ```

### Styling the Mermaid Graph
```mermaid
graph
    %% Node Definitions
    user((user))
    buy(buy button)
    signIn(signIn button)
    /thanks["`/thanks?stripeCheckoutSession`"]
    DB[(DB)]
    findStripeCheckoutSession{"`find Stripe Checkout Session in DB`"}
    checkifUserHasSomeWayToLoginAlready{"`check if User Has Some Way To Login Already in DB`"}
    thanksPage[["`thanksPage\n_check your email_`"]]
    /api/webhook[/"`/api/webhook\non checkout.session.completed`"/]
    checkIfFirstTimeUser{"`check if first time user`"}
    welcomeEmail[\"`verifyEmail\n_verify link_`"/]
    reactivateEmail[\"`reactivateEmail\n_for existing users_`"/]
    loginForm[["`loginForm\n_email and password fields_`"]]
    registerForm[["`registerForm\n_name, email and password fields_`"]]
    oAuth[["`oAuth provider\n_Google, Facebook, etc_`"]]
    /register
    registerAction>register action]

    %% Styling
    classDef default fill:#f4f4f8,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px;
    classDef important fill:#ffdddd,stroke:#f66,stroke-width:3px,color:#300;
    classDef action fill:#ddf,stroke:#39f,stroke-width:2px,color:#036;
    classDef database fill:#cfc,stroke:#393,stroke-width:2px,color:#060;

    %% Applying Styles
    class user,signIn,registerAction,loginForm,registerForm,thanksPage,oAuth important;
    class DB,database;
    class /thanks,findStripeCheckoutSession,checkifUserHasSomeWayToLoginAlready,checkIfFirstTimeUser action;
    class /api/webhook,welcomeEmail,reactivateEmail database;

    %% Connections
    user -->|clicks| buy
    buy -->|redirect onSuccess| /thanks
    /thanks --> findStripeCheckoutSession
    findStripeCheckoutSession -->|if found| checkifUserHasSomeWayToLoginAlready
    findStripeCheckoutSession <-.->|"`find **stripeCheckoutSession** by ID`"| DB
    findStripeCheckoutSession -->|if NOT found| thanksPage
    checkifUserHasSomeWayToLoginAlready <-.->|find user by email| DB
    signIn -->|redirects| /login
    checkifUserHasSomeWayToLoginAlready -->|YES| /login
    /login -->|"`clicks _Don't have and account yet?_ link`"| /register
    checkifUserHasSomeWayToLoginAlready -->|NO| /register
    buy -.->|stripe calls w/ payment events| /api/webhook
    /api/webhook -.->|"`**fulfillOrder**\nwrite to DB email:subscriptionDate`"| DB
    /api/webhook -.->|"`**saveCheckoutSession**\nwith sessionID`"| DB
    /api/webhook -->|send email| checkIfFirstTimeUser
    checkIfFirstTimeUser -->|YES| welcomeEmail
    checkIfFirstTimeUser -->|NO| reactivateEmail
    user -.->|"`checks email, after being told by **/thanks** page`"| welcomeEmail
    /login -->|has| oAuth
    /login -->|has| loginForm
    loginForm -->|submit correct credentials| app
    oAuth -.->|create User| DB
    oAuth -->|login| app
    app <-.->|checks subscription| DB
    user -->|clicks| signIn
    /register -->|has| oAuth
    /register -->|has| registerForm
    registerForm -->|submit name,email,password| registerAction
    oAuth -.->|create User| DB
    registerAction --> |send verifyEmail| welcomeEmail
    registerAction -.->|save credentials| DB
    welcomeEmail -->|user clicks emailLink| /verify
    /verify -.->|verifyEmail| DB
    /verify -->checkifUserHasSomeWayToLoginAlready
    app -->|if no active subscription| buy
```

### Explanation of Styling:
- **Default class**: Applied to all nodes, providing a clean and uniform background with subtle strokes.
- **Important class**: Used for primary interaction nodes like user inputs and decision points, highlighted with a red fill to draw attention.
- **Action class**: Designates nodes that involve action or process steps, styled with a blue fill for clarity.
- **Database class**: Specific to nodes interacting with the database, with a green fill to denote data operations.

This styled graph will help users visually differentiate between types of actions and flows in the authentication and purchase process, making it easier to follow and understand.

I'm curious, what are utm tags and how to correctly use them? could you suggest a better values for them here?

UTM tags are a great way to track the performance of your campaigns and understand how users interact with your website.

UTM tags are a way to add parameters to a URL that allows you to track the source, medium, campaign, content, and term of a user's visit. This information can then be used in analytics tools like Google Analytics to gain insights into your marketing efforts.

Here's a breakdown of each UTM tag:

1. **utm_source**: Identifies the source of the traffic (e.g., social media, email, paid advertising).
2. **utm_medium**: Identifies the marketing medium (e.g., email, social media, paid search).
3. **utm_campaign**: Identifies the specific campaign or promotion (e.g., summer sale, holiday promo).
4. **utm_content**: Identifies the specific content or ad that was clicked (e.g., banner ad, email link).
5. **utm_term**: Identifies the specific keyword or term that was targeted (e.g., "subscription expired").

In your case, you're using UTM tags to track the performance of the "Renew Subscription" CTA on the expired subscription page. Here's a suggestion for better values:

```
href={`${LANDING_WEBSITE_URL}?utm_source=expired_subscription&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=renew_subscription&utm_content=renew_cta&utm_term=expired_subscription_renewal`}
```

Here's a brief explanation for each value:

* **utm_source**: `expired_subscription` - indicates that the traffic is coming from an expired subscription page.
* **utm_medium**: `email` - indicates that the user received an email notification about their expired subscription.
* **utm_campaign**: `renew_subscription` - identifies the specific campaign or promotion (in this case, renewing a subscription).
* **utm_content**: `renew_cta` - identifies the specific content or ad that was clicked (in this case, the "Renew Subscription" CTA).
* **utm_term**: `expired_subscription_renewal` - identifies the specific keyword or term that was targeted (in this case, the renewal of an expired subscription).

By using these UTM tags, you'll be able to track the performance of your "Renew Subscription" campaign and gain insights into how users interact with your website.

config.systemRole: Your role as a full-stack web developer includes designing, developing, and maintaining both front-end and back-end web applications. You should have knowledge and experience in technologies such as HTML, CSS, JavaScript, as well as back-end programming languages such as Python, Java, Ruby. Experience with web frameworks such as React, Angular, Vue.js, Express, Django, Next.js, Flask, or Ruby on Rails is required. Experience with databases, application architecture, security, performance best practices, debugging, troubleshooting, and automated testing is also important. Collaborating with other developers, designers, and stakeholders is crucial for creating user-friendly web applications.

If a URL is provided, gather information about the product from there.
